In 1877, Thomas Edison invented the phonograph. Unlike the phonautograph, it was capable of both recording and reproducing sound. Despite the similarity of name, there is no documentary evidence that Edison's phonograph was based on Scott's phonautograph. Edison first tried recording sound on a wax-impregnated paper tape, with the idea of creating a "telephone repeater" analogous to the telegraph repeater he had been working on. Although the visible results made him confident that sound could be physically recorded and reproduced, his notes do not indicate that he actually reproduced sound before his first experiment in which he used tinfoil as a recording medium several months later. The tinfoil was wrapped around a grooved metal cylinder and a sound-vibrated stylus indented the tinfoil while the cylinder was rotated. The recording could be played back immediately. Tensions over rising Polish nationalism and the economic effects of the Continental System led to renewed confrontation with Russia. To enforce his blockade, Napoleon launched an invasion of Russia in the summer of 1812. The resulting campaign witnessed the catastrophic collapse of the Grand Army, forcing the French to retreat, as well as leading to the widespread destruction of Russian lands and cities. In 1813, Prussia and Austria joined Russian forces in a Sixth Coalition against France. A chaotic military campaign in Central Europe eventually culminated in a large Allied army defeating Napoleon at the Battle of Leipzig in October. The next year, the Allies invaded France and captured Paris, forcing Napoleon to abdicate in April 1814. He was exiled to the island of Elba. The Bourbons were restored to power and the French lost most of the territories that they had conquered since the Revolution. However, Napoleon escaped from Elba

In the Hesiodic Catalogue of Women, Graecus is presented as the son of Zeus and Pandora II, sister of Hellen the patriarch of Hellenes. Hellen was the son of Deucalion who ruled around Phthia in central Greece. The Parian Chronicle mentions that when Deucalion became king of Phthia, the previously called Graikoi were named Hellenes. Aristotle notes that the Hellenes were related with Grai/Greeks (Meteorologica I.xiv) a native name of a Dorian tribe in Epirus which was used by the Illyrians. He also claims that the great deluge must have occurred in the region around Dodona, where the Selloi dwelt. However, according to the Greek tradition it is more possible that the homeland of the Greeks was originally in central Greece. A modern theory derives the name Greek (Latin Graeci) from Graikos, "inhabitant of Graia/Graea," a town

In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and development of a biological cell or an organelle of a biological organism. Energy is thus often said to be stored by cells in the structures of molecules of substances such as carbohydrates (including sugars), lipids, and proteins, which release energy when reacted with oxygen in respiration. In human terms, the human equivalent (H-e) (Human energy conversion) indicates, for a given amount of energy expenditure, the relative quantity of energy needed for human metabolism, assuming an average human energy expenditure of 12,500 kJ per day and a basal metabolic rate of 80 watts. For example, if our bodies run (on average) at 80 watts, then a light bulb running at 100 watts is running at 1.25 human equivalents (100 ÷ 80) i.e. 1.25 H-e. Brazelton held up two stages in the summer of 1878 near Point of Mountain Station approximately 17 mi (27 km) northwest of Tucson. John Clum, of Tombstone, Arizona fame was one of the passengers. Brazelton was eventually tracked down and killed on Monday August 19, 1878, in a mesquite bosque along the Santa Cruz River 3 miles (5 km) south of Tucson by Pima County Sheriff Charles A. Shibell and his citizen's posse. Brazelton had been suspected of highway robbery not only in the Tucson area, but also in the Prescott region and Silver City, New Mexico area as well. In 633 AD, Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran and conquered it by 651 AD, largely converting Iranian people from their indigenous faiths of Manichaeism and Zoroastrianism to Sunni Islam. Arabic replaced Persian as the official language, while Persian remained the language of both ordinary people and of literature. Iran became a major contributor to the Islamic Golden Age, producing many influential scientists, scholars, artists, and thinkers. Establishment of the Safavid Dynasty in 1501, converted the Iranian people from Sunni Islam to Twelver Shia Islam, and made Twelver Shia Islam the official religion of Iran. Safavid conversion of Iran from Sunnism to Shiism marked one of the most important turning points in Iranian and Muslim history. Starting in 1736 under Nader Shah, Iran reached its greatest territorial extent since the Sassanid Empire, briefly possessing what was arguably the most powerful empire at the time. Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by efforts to regain the dignity and classicism of imperial Roman and Byzantine art, but was also influenced by the Insular art of the British Isles. Insular art integrated the energy of Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic styles of ornament with Mediterranean forms such as the book, and established many characteristics of art for the rest of the medieval period. Surviving religious works from the Early Middle Ages are mostly illuminated manuscripts and carved ivories, originally made for metalwork that has since been melted down. The brief peace in Europe allowed Napoleon to focus on the French colonies abroad. Saint-Domingue had managed to acquire a high level of political autonomy during the Revolutionary Wars, with Toussaint Louverture installing himself as de facto dictator by 1801. Napoleon saw his chance to recuperate the formerly wealthy colony when he signed the Treaty of Amiens. During the Revolution, the National Convention voted to abolish slavery in February 1794. Under the terms of Amiens, however, Napoleon agreed to appease British demands by not abolishing slavery in any colonies where the 1794 decree had never been implemented. The resulting Law of 20 May never applied to colonies like Guadeloupe or Guyane, even though rogue generals and other officials used the pretext of peace as an opportunity to reinstate slavery in some of these places. The Law of 20 May officially restored the slave trade to the Caribbean colonies, not slavery itself. Microsoft's philosophy is to provide customers with the best experience first, and allow them to make decisions themselves." The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid became standard texts in school curricula with which all educated Romans were familiar. Poets following Virgil often refer intertextually to his works to generate meaning in their own poetry. The Augustan poet Ovid parodies the opening lines of the Aeneid in Amores 1.1.1–2, and his summary of the Aeneas story in Book 14 of the Metamorphoses, the so-called "mini-Aeneid", has been viewed as a particularly important example of post-Virgilian response to the epic genre. Lucan's epic, the Bellum Civile has been considered an anti-Virgilian epic, disposing with the divine mechanism, treating historical events, and diverging drastically from Virgilian epic practice. The Flavian poet Statius in his 12-book epic Thebaid engages closely with the poetry of Virgil; in his epilogue he advises his poem not to "rival the divine Aeneid, but follow afar

By the early 18th century, the Maratha Kingdom had transformed itself into the Maratha Empire under the rule of the Peshwas (prime ministers). In 1737, the Marathas defeated a Mughal army in their capital, Delhi itself in Battle of Delhi (1737). He explained it with the example of Malwa region. Marathas built an efficient system of public administration known for its attention to detail. Throughout the history of the South Slavs, the vernacular, literary, and written languages (e.g. Chakavian, Kajkavian, Shtokavian) of the various regions and ethnicities developed and diverged independently. Prior to the 19th century, they were collectively called "Illyric", "Slavic", "Slavonian", "Bosnian", "Dalmatian", "Serbian" or "Croatian". As such, the term Serbo-Croatian was first used by Jacob Grimm in 1824, popularized by the Vienna philologist Jernej Kopitar in the following decades, and accepted by Croatian Zagreb grammarians in 1854 and 1859. At that time, Serb and Croat lands were still part of the Ottoman and Austrian Empires. Officially, the language was called variously Serbo-Croat, Croato-Serbian, Serbian and Croatian, Croatian and Serbian, Serbian or Croatian, Croatian or Serbian. By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury's first launch. On April 12, 1961, the USSR surprised the world again by launching Yuri Gagarin into a single orbit around the Earth in a craft they called Vostok 1. They dubbed Gagarin the first cosmonaut, roughly translated from Russian and Greek as "sailor of the universe". Although he had the ability to take over manual control of his spacecraft in an emergency by opening an envelope he had in the cabin that contained a code that could be typed into the computer, it was flown in an automatic mode as a precaution; medical science at that time did not know what would happen to a human in the weightlessness of space. The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the last volcanic eruptions occurred about 7 million years ago). Coastal areas are covered in volcanic rock and warmer and drier than the centre. The highest point of the island is Diana's Peak at 818 m (2,684 ft). In 1996 it became the island's first national park. Much of the island is covered by New Zealand flax, a legacy of former industry, but there are some original trees augmented by plantations, including those of the Millennium Forest project which was established in 2002 to replant part of the lost Great Wood and is now managed by the Saint Helena National Trust. When the island was discovered, it was covered with unique indigenous vegetation, including a remarkable cabbage tree species. In January 1938, Milt Gabler started recording for his new label, Commodore Records, and to allow for longer continuous performances, he recorded some 12-inch records. On 1 September 1870, the battle opened with the Army of Châlons, with 202 infantry battalions, 80 cavalry squadrons and 564 guns, attacking the surrounding Prussian Third and Meuse Armies totaling 222 infantry battalions, 186 cavalry squadrons and 774 guns. General De Wimpffen, the commander of the French V Corps in reserve, hoped to launch a combined infantry and cavalry attack against the Prussian XI Corps. But by 11:00, Prussian artillery took a toll on the French while more Prussian troops arrived on the battlefield. The French cavalry, commanded by General Marguerite, launched three desperate attacks on the nearby village of Floing where the Prussian XI Corps was concentrated. Marguerite was killed leading the very first charge and the two additional charges led to nothing but heavy losses. By the end of the day, with no hope of breaking out, Napoleon III called off the attacks. The French lost over 17,000 men, killed or wounded, with 21,000 captured. The Prussians reported their losses at 2,320

John treated the interdict as "the equivalent of a papal declaration of war". He responded by attempting to punish Innocent personally and to drive a wedge between those English clergy that might support him and those allying themselves firmly with the authorities in Rome. John seized the lands of those clergy unwilling to conduct services, as well as those estates linked to Innocent himself; he arrested the illicit concubines that many clerics kept during the period, only releasing them after the payment of fines; he seized the lands of members of the church who had fled England, and he promised protection for those clergy willing to remain loyal to him. In many cases, individual institutions were able to negotiate terms for managing their own properties and keeping the produce of their estates. By 1209 the situation showed no signs of resolution, and Innocent threatened to excommunicate John if he did not acquiesce to Langton's appointment.

At each goal line is a set of 40-foot-high (12 m) goalposts, which consist of two uprights joined by an 18 1⁄2-foot-long (5.6 m) crossbar which is 10 feet (3 m) above the goal line. The goalposts may be H-shaped (both posts fixed in the ground) although in the higher-calibre competitions the tuning-fork design (supported by a single curved post behind the goal line, so that each post starts 10 feet (3 m) above the ground) is preferred. The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has grown in recent times for economic purposes. The number of successful interspecific mammalian hybrids is relatively small, although it has come to be known that there is a significant number of naturally occurring hybrids between forms or regional varieties of a single species.[citation needed] These may form zones of gradation known as clines. Indeed, the distinction between some hitherto distinct species can become clouded once it can be shown that they may not only breed but produce fertile offspring. Some hybrid animals exhibit greater strength and resilience than either parent. This is known as hybrid vigor. The existence of the mule (donkey sire; horse dam) being used widely as a hardy draught animal throughout ancient and modern history is testament to this. A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, is the simple belief in God the Creator, with no reference to the Bible or any other miraculous source. Instead, the Deist relies solely on personal reason to guide his creed, which was eminently agreeable to many thinkers of the time. Atheism was much discussed, but there were few proponents. Wilson and Reill note that, "In fact, very few enlightened intellectuals, even when they were vocal critics of Christianity, were true atheists. Rather, they were critics of orthodox belief, wedded rather to skepticism, deism, vitalism, or perhaps pantheism." Some followed Pierre Bayle and argued that atheists could indeed be moral men. BYU has 21 NCAA varsity teams. Nineteen of these teams played mainly in the Mountain West Conference from its inception in 1999 until the school left that conference in 2011. Prior to that time BYU teams competed in the Western Athletic Conference. All teams are named the "Cougars", and Cosmo the Cougar has been the school's mascot since 1953. The school's fight song is the Cougar Fight Song. Because many of its players serve on full-time missions for two years (men when they're 18, women when 19), BYU athletes are often older on average than other schools' players. The NCAA allows students to serve missions for two years without subtracting that time from their eligibility period. Of major Canadian cities, St. John's is the foggiest (124 days), windiest (24.3 km/h (15.1 mph) average speed), and cloudiest (1,497 hours of sunshine). St. John's experiences milder temperatures during the winter season in comparison to other Canadian cities, and has the mildest winter for any Canadian city outside of British Columbia. Precipitation is frequent and often heavy, falling year round. On average, summer is the driest season, with only occasional thunderstorm activity, and the wettest months are from October to January, with December the wettest single month, with nearly 165 millimetres of precipitation on average. This winter precipitation maximum is quite unusual for humid continental climates, which most commonly have a late spring or early summer precipitation maximum (for example, most of the Midwestern U.S.).

The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s. Catholics rallied up around the team and listen to the games on the radio, especially when it knocked off the schools that symbolized the Protestant establishment in America — Harvard, Yale, Princeton, and Army. Yet this role as high-profile flagship institution of Catholicism made it an easy target of anti-Catholicism. The most remarkable episode of violence was the clash between Notre Dame students and the Ku Klux Klan in 1924. Nativism and anti-Catholicism, especially when directed towards immigrants, were cornerstones of the KKK's rhetoric, and Notre Dame was seen as a symbol of the threat posed by the Catholic Church. The Klan decided to have a week-long Klavern in South Bend. Clashes with the student body started on March 17, when students, aware of the anti-Catholic animosity, blocked the Klansmen from descending from their trains in the South Bend

Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: the Swiss Alps to the south, the Swiss Plateau or Central Plateau, and the Jura mountains on the west. The Alps are a high mountain range running across the central-south of the country, comprising about 60% of the country's total area. The majority of the Swiss population live in the Swiss Plateau. Among the high valleys of the Swiss Alps many glaciers are found, totalling an area of 1,063 square kilometres (410 sq mi). From these originate the headwaters of several major rivers, such as the Rhine, Inn, Ticino and Rhône, which flow in the four cardinal directions into the whole of Europe. Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) isotherm, the city lies within the transition zone from a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) to a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa), although the suburbs north and west of the city are significantly colder in winter and solidly fall under the latter categorization; the city lies at the transition between USDA plant hardiness zones 6b (most of the city) and 7a (Downtown, South Boston, and East Boston neighborhoods). Summers are typically warm to hot, rainy, and humid, while winters oscillate between periods of cold rain and snow, with cold temperatures. Spring and fall are usually mild, with varying conditions dependent on wind direction and jet stream positioning. As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf. In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that the madrasa, as a charitable endowment, will remain under the control of the donor (and their descendent), resulted in a "spurt" of establishment of madaris in the 11th and 12th centuries. However, in Western Islamic lands, where the Maliki views prohibited donors from controlling their endowment, madaris were not as popular. Unlike the corporate designation of Western institutions of higher learning, the waqf designation seemed to have led to the exclusion of non-orthodox religious subjects such a philosophy and natural science from the curricula. The madrasa of al-Qarawīyīn, one of the two surviving madaris that predate the founding of the earliest medieval universities and are thus claimed to be the "first universities" by some authors, has acquired official university status as late as 1947. An adolescent's environment plays a huge role in their identity development. While most adolescent studies are conducted on white, middle class children, studies show that when the same adolescents are given a different, but similar home setting, they develop a similar self-concept and attitudes.

One of the main reasons that adolescence is a stressful time is that it is developmental. During this time, adolescents are dealing with the issues of peer pressure, identity, sexuality, social status, social class, school etc. Since many of these problems overlap, there aren’t single solutions. One solution comes from an effective setting for adolescent development, their peers and surrounding environment.

Compared to other team sports, the National Football League preseason is very structured. Intense media interest in the opinions and private lives of the royal family during the 1980s led to a series of sensational stories in the press, damaging to both the family's image and the royal brand. In reaction to this, the royal household commissioned the first "official" media policy, the Household Policy Document, which was first published in February 1983.

It defined the family's position not only as Queen and head of state, but also as subjects and members of the wider royal family. In its place, the Policy Document has subsequently evolved into the present-day royal press code, which provides guidance on how the monarchy's communications should be approached.

Royal Code

Since the late 1980s, the royal code, which is also known as the media code, has acted as an important protection against the influence of the press.

To extend and consolidate the dynasty's control in Central Asia, the Kangxi Emperor personally led a series of military campaigns against the Dzungars (Dzungars, also spelled Zungars, Russian: Dzhungars, also pronounced zhundgars) and the Mongols. These campaigns ended in the defeat of the Dzungars by a larger force from the west. The campaign against the Mongols that started in 1245 continued for another thirty years (1251–1279) and ended in a defeat. The Dzungars were forced to move into the steppe regions to the west or south. Their center of power remained with Togarmahal near Amu Darya. During this time the Mongols and the Khazars had expanded their control south to the Black Sea, into Georgia and Central Asia.

From the 1970s onward, Stuart Hall's pioneering work, along with that of his colleagues Paul Willis, Dick Hebdige, Tony Jefferson, Andrew Hacker, Martin Nowlin, Philip Pettitt and more, has influenced every aspect of the field of sociology as we know it. The seminal work was the seminal text book on the subject on which his name is still so widely associated: sociology and the individual, 1968. Mammalian hair, also known as pelage, can vary in color between populations, organisms within a population, and even on the individual organism. The exact same coloration (i.e., gray or brown in different mammals) can be present in different populations of the same species, yet between populations of the same species or within a single population of a higher order of organism. For example, human hair can be of gray color in North America where it is associated with a particular racial group. In Europe, it is associated with another racial group. The variation in hair color among the various European races is even more striking for the populations in Australia and Asia where the populations are considerably farther apart.
The variation in hair color or pigmentation can contribute to the differentiation of species and allow differentiation of individuals. However, hair color may also induce diseases. But in the mid-18th century, during the French Enlightenment, a more ideological use of the term had come into use. In 1765, the French politician and essayist Voltaire published a book arguing that the religious foundations of the modern state were insufficient. “Our laws ought to be founded upon a system of morals,” he wrote. “This would make us free and great.”

Voltaire’s critics pointed out that his own philosophy lacked the “social guarantees” that were necessary for the state to be both free and great. “A person ought to be free to do as he likes,” Voltaire insisted, “and to love whom he likes,” but he added, “so far as I know, you don’t have this right.” To be free, he argued, “one ought also to love.”

Emotions can motivate social interactions and relationships and therefore are directly related with basic physiology, particularly with the stress systems. This is important because emotions are involved, especially strong emotional reactions, in the pathogenesis of physical and mental illnesses. Emotion regulation is generally defined as a set of biological and physiological mechanisms that promote the optimal expression of different social outcomes, such as prosocial vs. antisocial behaviors and social reward. In addition to the stress response system, social reward is related to affectivity (i.e., emotions) and reward processing, a result that also has bearing to psychopathological outcomes. Based on these studies, the role of emotion in regulating social interaction is crucial for promoting prosocial behaviors and health and social outcomes. This has important consequences for public health. Jeffrey Long and Rick Kittles give a long critique of the application of FST to human populations in their 2003 paper "Human Genetic Diversity and Human Evolution."

However, if you're a paleoanthropologist, a geneticist, and read the book, it's hard to argue with these authors' conclusions.

Long and Kittles note that there is no FST data for Homo sapiens -- just Neanderthals and homo erectus. They also note that FST appears to "not be appropriate for estimating the frequency of specific alleles in non-Homo ancestors." Long and Kittles also look at another data point -- that of frequency of each SNP in homo sapiens. The book was widely translated in Darwin's lifetime, but problems arose with translating concepts and metaphors, and some translations were biased by the translator's own ideals. In the 1960s, a group of biologists and linguists discussed the problem and eventually came to the conclusion that English should be a neutral common language, with the most suitable common words chosen for expression. They also decided that English should be a written language that is not dependent upon spoken language as a medium for communication. Since written English was a new language (with unknown vocabulary and pronunciation) and most Darwin followers were illiterate when he wrote the book, it was decided that it would be easier for modern westerners to grasp his ideas if they read and understood the book than if they had to depend upon memorization and interpretation of complicated, outdated concepts and words. After much study, they finally came to the conclusion that to make the most of Darwin's work, the translation of the book as written was not acceptable.

Hegel certainly intends to preserve what he takes to be true of German idealism, in particular Kant's insistence that ethical reason can and does trump all else, including politics. But it is not for this reason that we should follow him. We should seek inspiration in another direction, namely, from the classical idealism of the Greeks. Hegel is entirely wrong to say that modernity is essentially secular, while the ancient world was dominated by religion. The classical world—Greek and Roman—was equally dependent on religion, but to a different extent.

In southeast Europe agrarian societies first appeared in the 7th millennium BC, attested by one of the earliest farming sites of Europe, discovered in the Romanian city of Craiova (now in Romania). The agricultural society, which was a mix of both Sumerian and Phoenician influences, developed its own unique methods of crop cultivation, livestock breeding, and water resources management. In the next centuries, the population of the region continued to expand, and the population began to settle down in larger villages, towns, and larger cities, which became the cultural foundations of cities to come. The agricultural society continued to spread over the Eurasian steppe and later was replaced by different societies, each reflecting a different culture- and/or a different ideology, such as the nomadic or sedentary. As the population of the region continued to increase, the population began to settle down in larger cities, towns, and larger villages, which became the cultural foundations for cities to come. Knowledge, for Popper, was objective, both in the sense that it is objectively true (or truthlike), and also in the sense that its truth can be defined in terms of reality; it thus exists in the sense that reality exists. (In contrast, subjective truth is an entity in and of itself, independent of reality, i.e., it does not exist in and of itself in the same way that facts exist: instead, being is the foundation on which knowledge is based, and we can only know about the object of knowledge as we know about ourselves, and the world we live in.)

Knowledge, according to Popper, thus has a twofold relationship to reality: first, an objective truthlike relation; second, a subjective truthlike property.

Objective truth

Strict separation of powers did not operate in The United Kingdom, the political structure of which served in most instances[citation needed] as a safeguard against the accumulation of too much legislative power within any one branch of government. The first example of this concept in the British system lay in the Royal Charter of 1065. The charter contained a clause forbidding King Henry II to interfere in the internal affairs of Church of England and to grant himself a spiritual supremacy over it.

In Britain's Parliamentary democracy there was a continuous debate surrounding the powers of Parliament. As far back as the 1540s monarchs had been concerned about this issue, and in 1555 King Edward VII agreed with the idea of a strong standing Parliament. The Parliamentary Model came about only after more than 150 years of debate within the House of Commons. Although Ottoman madaris had a number of different branches of study, such as calligraphic sciences, oral sciences, and intellectual sciences, they primarily served the students of higher education. Madaris, then, operated as community of interest for higher education. This chapter will compare students from the Ottoman madaris with students of English madaris to see the difference in the kind of students served, their attitudes towards women, the roles of women in the society, and the way they taught the subjects of the madaris.

A number of madaris, as an institution, were more traditional. Madaris with their traditional approach did have an educational structure but they did not allow women to get educated, which was against the nature of the madrasas. Another difference was that the madaris had a more formal education for the students. Madaris in the Ottoman period allowed women to study, but did not force them to. Instead, they allowed women to learn on their own terms.

The landscapes of Thuringia are quite diverse. The far north is occupied by the Harz mountains, followed by the Goldene Aue, a mountain area in the north-west. The central lowland, as seen from the Harz Mountains, is dotted with many small villages, but towards the west the landscapes are more isolated and less wild. These areas can be reached by foot from a main road, but even by bicycle. It is a great cycling destination and there are many cycle routes.

Throughout the 14th century, French kings sought to expand their influence at the expense of the territorial holdings of the nobility. They ran into difficulties when they were also challenged by the growing power of the Church. The church, for reasons that still require investigation, resisted any effort to convert more than the small elite of monks and nuns that they permitted in the kingdom at this time.

Thus the king’s attempts to convert the clergy to faith on his side were generally unsuccessful. In general he relied on the local lords to do the heavy lifting and to persuade their lordships’ people to abandon their faith for the state religious system. This method worked in the region around Brittany at least as far back as the 11th century when the counts of Foix were converted in exchange for the crown’s security guarantees and the provision of royal lands for royal churches.

The Jurassic Period extends from about 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 Ma. During the early Jurassic, the supercontinent Pangaea was breaking apart, which resulted in island arcs within modern-day Europe, Africa, and Asia.[2] The Cretaceous–Paleogene Extinction event (K-Pg extinction) was caused by the largest (up to 15km) asteroid impact in all of geological history. By the time the meteor struck an area of what is now North or South America,[2] the continents had separated as Pangaea had broken into Gondwana. North America was part of a larger land mass known as Pangea, which was to evolve into Pangaea. Most of today's Americas were part of a larger land mass called Pangaea, called Australasia, that stretched from South America to Australia. These continents collided and created the island arcs of Scotland and Ireland, which formed a part of modern day Great Britain.

The highest position in Islam, caliphate, was claimed by the sultans starting since Murad I, which was established as Ottoman Caliphate. In the post-Mursi era, the office has been officially renamed to grand imam.[12][14]

After the demise of the Ottoman Empire, Muslims continued as Muslims in the newly-established Arab State of Egypt. The first caliph was al-Hakim in the 11th century. After the conquest of the Levant by the Mamluks in 1291, the caliphate was re-established in Cairo. But soon afterwards, another leader rose to power and was recognized by the Muslims as Caliph. This was Muhammad ibn Abd al-Barr al-Maqrawi and he was known as the Caliph of Egypt until his death in 1434. It is in this year when the office of Caliph shifted to the city of Al-Azhar. The city of Jerusalem is of special importance to Jews, Muslims and Christians as it is the home of sites that are pivotal to their religious beliefs, and their histories.

On August 5, 2016, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu officially declared the "Nation State of the Jewish People" bill, after many Jewish communities in Israel submitted applications to make Jerusalem their official capital.

The bill stated "Jerusalem will be the national, historic and united capital of the State of Israel."

While this is a major victory for Jewish advocates within Israel, many Palestinian advocates within the West Bank, including the West Bank and Gaza, who see Jerusalem as the heart of their own future state, condemn the bill as a threat to the city's integrity, if not outright destruction.

This has raised a question about what these groups believe is the Jewish right to claim Jerusalem — by historical means, or legal?

The area now called Galicia was first inhabited by humans during the Middle Paleolithic period, and it takes its name from the Gallaeci people called Gallaeci. Galician people spoke Celtic languages, which became a part of Latin and later to Spanish.

Galicia was made a duchy as early as 740 by Pope Gregory II. In 1145, Spain conquered the duchy (now known as the Principality Castile) from Portugal. The land had previously been ruled by the Moors, the Celts and the Iberians; eventually it was held and subdued by the Spanish Crown. Galician people have held a status of autonomy since 1640. At present, most of Galicia is controlled by the autonomous community of the Principality of Asturias; however, the remaining areas outside that territory are ruled by the Royal Government of Galicia (the Government of Regions) as part of the Kingdom of Spain. Birds have a very efficient system for diffusing oxygen into the blood; birds have a ten times greater surface area to gas exchange volume than mammals and a million times more than reptiles. (The birds who had flown the distance to reach South America, for example, could probably fill a gas oven ten times their total body mass in a single hour, and their blood has a capacity of almost 400 liters per cubic millimeter.) To find out if birds' higher gas exchange rates translate into better immune systems, the scientists took blood from 23 common house sparrows and one European starling, and examined the proteins and nucleic acids found in the proteins. As anticipated by Nimitz, the Japanese fleet arrived off Midway on 4 June and was spotted by PBY patrol aircraft. Nagumo executed a rapid attack on the base, using six destroyers and one other ship to inflict severe damage (see "Japanese Raid"). When the attack was over, Japanese destroyers proceeded to surround the Midway base. Some of the planes and aircraft were able to escape, but most were trapped in the Midway base. The survivors (excluding the two missing aircraft) were then taken by submarine and forced into the sea, where many crews died and some were captured.
The US Navy attempted a rescue by dispatching several aircraft carriers (including Enterprise, Ford, and Lexington—see "Rescue of Midway Survivors") to Midway, but the air force was ineffective at flying the plane to safety because of bad weather.

Identity development is a stage in the adolescent life cycle. For most, the search for identity begins in the adolescent years. During these years, a large and important part of their lives, an adolescent tries to discover and express their unique sense of self. Adolescents are seeking to develop their sense of selves and the expression of their thoughts and beliefs within the community in which they live. Identity formation is important because it leads to a mature adjustment to their environment. Identities shape identity; they reflect who the adolescent is. Identity is defined as a collection of characteristics about oneself that are held with high esteem. Idenity is the primary psychological tool used by adolescents during this period to express social, sexual, and affective identity.

Identity development during adolescence is important primarily for its affective component.

Egocentrism in adolescents forms a self-conscious desire to feel important in their peer groups and enjoy social acceptance. Unlike the conflicting aspects of their identities explored in previous research, research into self-concept development in adolescents has focused predominantly on external features like personality traits and values. This research investigates how egocentrism develops during the adolescence. In order to better understand this process, the authors utilize experimental and self-report methods to examine the effects of self-concept development on the development of adolescents' external features. In order to determine whether self-concept development influences whether adolescents will be more or less externalistic, research was conducted with 7th grade adolescents and adolescents with and without a history of eating disorders. With the results of the analyses, the authors concluded that adolescents with more extreme egocentrism tended to have more externalistic tendencies.

Stanley Schachter formulated his theory on the earlier work of a Spanish physician, Gregorio Marañón, who injected patients with epinephrine to stimulate the heart. Schachter applied his theory to the treatment of syphilis. (I believe he was the first person to use the term, “autoinoculation.”) The syphilis was not the initial problem — Schachter had made his living treating syphilis — but the autoinoculation. Schachter made the syphilis worse by injecting syphilis bacteria into some of the treated patients’ arteries.

Schachter’s theory was developed from a Spanish practice that had been known in the 19th century. During that era, physicians would insert iron pins into the livers of patients with a form of syphilis, a form known as congenital syphilis.

Hong Taiji's bureaucracy was staffed with many Han Chinese, including many newly surrendered Ming officials. The Manchus' continued dominance was ensured by a very wealthy Han elite, which included many Han businessmen and merchants that had been relocated to Beijing due to the War of Succession. The Han elite in and around Beijing did not always support Qing rule, but nevertheless benefited greatly from the Qing's protection economy and trade relations. Han Chinese lived and worked within the Manchu system, and were highly respected across both political and social sectors.

The Han Chinese were the first major ethnic group to be subject to the Qing government and were instrumental, in the later stages of the Qing empire, in establishing Han Chinese civil society and political authority. The Han Chinese, who also became the majority of Manchu China's military and civil administration by the end of the Qing, built the Han society that we see today.

Y DNA studies tend to imply a small number of founders in an old population whose members parted and followed different migration paths. In most Jewish populations, Y DNA has a strong haplogroup tendency, i.e. it is likely to reflect a particular lineage of migrants. This makes it very likely that there were ancient populations (either related or unrelated to Jews in particular) which did not contain a common founder.

The situation in Britain is rather different. Because the ancestors of the British are likely to have dispersed many times, and not all of them reached Britain, there can be a broad range of haplogroups found in Britain. For example, at the top of my test page I show (below), that all (but one) of the British Y samples have a haplogroup (Hb) between 16 and 23, most commonly found in North Africa and Morocco.

Even more interesting is that a large number of British Y chromosomes have an Hb of 23-24

In contemporary society, adolescents also face some risks as their sexuality begins to transform. While some of these, such as emotional distress (fear of losing their family), may have an obvious immediate impact, some of the more subtle issues can have very long-term and sometimes catastrophic impacts.

As an adolescent’s sexuality is emerging, this new experience is often met with the desire to explore other options and try other things. From a purely psychological point of view, the desire is justified. Sexual fantasies are, for the most part, based on an ‘other’, and while being able to experience such encounters will satisfy a part of the brain, it can also open up a Pandora’s box of other sexual and emotional responses to experiences that had once been closed down as not being acceptable. The deeper ancestral demography of Bermuda's population has been obscured by the ethnic homogenisation of the last four centuries. There is effectively no ethnic diversity, and the ethnic minority populations were not large enough to become important until recent (19th and 20th centuries) arrivals.

The body’s capability to react to antigen depends on a person's age, antigen type, maternal factors and the area where the antigen is located. The capacity of a person's immune system to recognize antigen may have a significant impact on the magnitude of inflammation associated with diseases and disorders with which the immune system may be in contact with the host’s tissues and organs. The immune system is able to effectively provide host defense against foreign antigens by triggering a response in host cells.

In the human body, the immune system is coordinated by the lymphoid cells of specific subgroups known as lymphoid organs. The lymphoid organs include, for example, the liver, spleen, kidney, bone marrow, spleen, bone marrow, and bone. Each organ has separate and unique lymphoid subsets. For example, the bone marrow produces the blood cells and monocytes, the spleen produces B lymphocytes, platelets and white blood cells.

The report said the military “wreaked havoc” on villages by deploying heavy trucks to move supplies “everywhere, indiscriminately”.

The Ministry of Defence has been accused of polluting Britain's countryside with a system of mass rubbish dumps (PA)

There were up to 20 such dumps at any one time and the Royal Household supplied them, which caused a serious strain on the local ecology.

The report suggested that up to 30,000 tonnes of waste were dumped in the South East of England.

Public priests were appointed by the collegia. Once elected, a priest held permanent religious authority from the eternal divine, which offered him lifetime influence, not just a particular congregation. Therefore, a priest remained more closely tied with local government, or the bishop, throughout his life.[3]

Although the word episcopos has often been mistakenly used in English literature to refer to "head" or "supremacy"; it is often meant to convey more of the spirit, meaning the authority of a bishop or diocesan leader. In the early Church, the supreme bishop (bishopos) was not a bishop, but a prelate (pastor) who would also sometimes lead a particular diocese.

The title episcopus was therefore common enough that by the sixth century it had become a word for a bishop (although in later Western texts it often remains only a word for an archbishop).

"Episcopus" also referred to other prelates

More than any other country in the world the U.S. is concerned with security. Many modern specialty matches have been devised, with unique winning conditions. The most common of these is the ladder match. In the basic ladder match, wrestlers appear on an elevated structure with holes in the sides. They are not locked into the holes but have the ability to slide down the ladder. Each wrestler has to grab one of their legs on the other side of the ladder and make a 90 degree turn, holding one leg in the left hole (the right leg in the right hole) and the other leg in the right hole, and attempt to scale down the ladder. If a wrestler manages to climb up a ladder to the top and hold the ladder, they win. This method is commonly used for tag teams and tag matches.

A true predator can commonly be known as one that kills and eats another living thing. Whereas other types of predator all harm their prey in some way (either directly or by inflicting their own wounds, by catching, devouring, or by hunting them to death; see predator-prey relationship), a true predator simply kills (that is to say, doesn't simply devour) or consumes their prey. Predators can be either ectobiologists (like carnivores) or endotherms (like herbivores).

Contents

Endotherms

An endothermatite is a species of mammal with a body temperature maintained by the burning of fat or other organic matter. The term specifically refers to the use of combustion for the purposes of thermal energy production within the body of a mammal. This term has been used by zoologists since the 19th century.[2]

In 680 Ibn al-Zubayr fled Medina for Mecca. Hearing about Husayn's opposition to Yazid I, the people of Kufa declared him their new Caliph, and he was made their new ruler. He made a pilgrimage, returned to Medina, and called a grand assembly at Kufa. During it, he gathered troops and marched on Baghdad.

The siege of Baghdad was begun and victory was won. The next day, his forces took Mecca. He was proclaimed the prophet's successor, and the followers of Husayn and Yazid fled to Safad and Yathrib. Ibn Zuhayr had the city of Bani Hasan in Iraq under siege. The followers of Yazid fled as it fell. Yazid finally surrendered and went to Mecca.

In 696, Yazid asked for the return of the remains of Muhammad ibn Abdullah and al-Hashim, but Ibn Zuhayr had them burnt at Kufa.

The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo, signed on February 2, 1848, by American diplomat Nicholas Trist and Mexican plenipotentiary José María Morelos at the U.S. embassy in Mexico City, opened relations between Texas and the United States as states. The terms of the treaty stipulated that the United States granted Mexico the territory west of the Rio Grande and the United States would enter into a military alliance for 20 years on the Mexican side. The treaty was also the basis for the United States purchasing Texan and Mexican lands to form the Texas Colony, which soon became the state of Texas.

By the 1890s, there were more than 100,000 Mexican and U.S. colonists and settlers living along the Rio Grande and the Gulf of Mexico, including the area that would eventually become a county and state: McAllen, Texas. The Royal Assent ceremony takes place in the Senate, as the sovereign is traditionally barred from the House of Commons. On the day of the event, the sovereign and members of the royal family are presented to the House of Commons prior to the Queen asking the House of Commons to 'acknowledge and approve' the Bill. The monarch is then allowed to enter the chamber of the House of Commons and deliver an Address. It is an important element of the monarch's constitutional role.

The Queen has to be invited or granted an audience with the Speaker of the House of Commons by the President of the Senate, before a Bill may be considered (if the Speaker believes it is incompatible with the Queen's status, the President may refuse to consider the Bill).

From his diagrams of a small number of particles interacting in spacetime, Feynman could then model all of physics in terms of the spins of the particles and their interaction.

The final major aspect of identity formation is self-esteem. Self-esteem is defined as one's thoughts and feelings about one's self-concept (who you are, how you feel about yourself, and your worth to the world), and is central to mental and physical health, as well as family, school, social, and professional life. Self-esteem also is linked to other psychological health aspects such as life history and personal growth. This chapter focuses on how self-esteem interacts with other identity components to affect the development of youth and adult identity.

When John's elder brother Richard became king in September 1189, he had already declared his intention of joining the Third Crusade. Richard set about raising a force in 10 provinces, but the outbreak of strife with his sister, Margaret of Anjou, prevented his returning to the west. Richard died at Boulogne on 15 July and was buried in Westminster Abbey in London. With the coronation of Henry II, his eldest son Edward inherited his claim to the throne. Although in 1069 Edward had married a daughter of Philip of Hainaut, whose brother Henry II came to be known as "Little Henry," Edward had never directly inherited the title of Plantagenet, and he was never a "son" of the Plantagenets either as a result of his mother's marriage or birth. He was therefore known for the rest of his life simply as "the Son of the Black Prince."

Though Britain and the empire emerged victorious from the Second World War, the effects of the conflict were profound, both at home and abroad. Much of British public opinion in the immediate postwar period focused on the loss of empire – as well as on the welfare of the working class and other nationalities.

The government’s postwar manifesto, the 1951 Labour Party constitution, and most of the national press provided an implicit vision of a peaceful and prosperous post-war Britain in which the common ownership of the means of production would be maintained.

This led many to assume that the war would lead directly to the social democratic project that had dominated Labour politics since the party’s inception. But at the same time, the war effort, and the need to build a massive peacetime economy, presented the British state with new challenges. How could such demands coexist with the established political and material world order, and with an increasingly assertive international Britain?

On 13 March, the upper Clyde port of Clydebank near Glasgow was bombed. All but seven of its 12,000 houses were damaged. This is the worst attack in the city since the Second World War: around 70% of civilian casualties were children.

In the weeks leading up to the bombing, many people had been evacuated to Glasgow city centre. In some areas, the people had been given only a couple of days notice about moving. For some of the displaced people, the bombing of their homes took them back to the place they had been forced to flee three years earlier.

The bombing also caused mass confusion and panic. There were widespread incidents of gunfire in the city, and there was a great deal of looting. By the evening, some 60 cars had been stolen from their owners. In total, more than 1,500 people were arrested for rioting. By far the largest military action in which the United States engaged during this era was the War of 1812. With Britain locked in a major war with France, the United States was left to fight alone against other powers in its own backyard.

The American-Canadian conflict was sparked by a dispute over the British construction of a fort on American soil — the dispute would eventually lead to the War of 1812. During this war, the United States occupied the province of Upper Canada, while Britain possessed the province of Lower Canada — or the Canadas for short.

The war was brief. In just four months, the United States claimed the island of Montreal after a British expeditionary force in Quebec, and the American army was able to quickly occupy most of Upper Canada.

The Treaty of Ghent in the United States-Canada Agreement ended the war and established a new status quo for Upper and Lower Canada, which resulted in the Canadian province becoming the new American province of Louisiana.

The United States has become essentially a two-party system. Since a conservative (such as the Republican Party) and liberal (such as the Democratic Party) dominate the election process, any candidate who is associated with a particular party will be voted into office, even if the candidate has far better policy alternatives. Voters also tend to take the issue of race very seriously, and thus, support candidates that are perceived as being more “pure” and “tolerant” of others. As a result, many candidates may have little or no chance in a district that has a very high-profile candidate in that particular race, such as a senator or a presidential candidate. Candidates must now carefully navigate around the two-party system in order to have a decent chance at winning office.

Early Modern universities initially continued the curriculum and research of the Middle Ages: natural philosophy, logic, medicine, theology, mathematics, astronomy (and astrology), music and languages (including the language known as alchemy, which was not really discovered until the 1690s). By the sixteenth century (the year of Leibniz), European universities began to incorporate modern fields into the programs offered to students (including the study of astronomy, which was often done in the universities of Prague and Vienna). The medieval curriculum had been largely a matter of faith.

From the beginning of the Renaissance, however, European universities and schools of learning were under the influence of the European Enlightenment (commonly denoted as the Age of Reason) and the humanism (a mixture of humanism and philosophy) of Aristotle, Descartes, Leibniz and Locke.

But as the human genome has been deciphered, these milestones have become more and more arbitrary. These differences have led biologists to explore the relationship between hormones and sexual identity.

Following the Ulm Campaign, French forces managed to capture Vienna in November. The Daily Northwestern is the main student newspaper. It is one of the largest student-owned newspapers in the country. The Daily Northwestern features the voices of students, as well as regular columns written by faculty, staff, government officials, and other notable figures. With over 3 million population and its capital Tallinn on the Baltic Sea, Estonia is the third-largest country in the EU, which currently accounts for 75% of its trade.

Estonia's trade with the European Union represents over three-fourths of its exports. In 2013, Estonia registered a trade surplus with the EU of EUR 1.9 billion. In 2015, the foreign trade deficit was EUR 1.1 billion.

Estonian imports are dominated by energy resources (mostly coal and oil); metals and nonconventional petroleum, with the bulk of its oil imports coming from Russia. Estonian exports include machinery, foodstuffs, capital goods and equipment.

Estonia's main trading partners outside the EU are Russia, China, and Sweden.

The political structure of Western Europe changed with the end of the united Roman Empire. Although the movements of peoples during this period are usually described as "colonial" and "imperial", historians sometimes refer to them as "barbarian invasions" to avoid implying a political meaning. A new structure evolved with the coming of the first European invaders, and its consequences shaped the medieval world for centuries to come.

Preparations for invasion had already begun by the time the Romans fell in the Year of the Four Emperors (93–4) from the combined forces of their long-dominant Greek colonies and the recently minted barbarian tribes. Before the advent of the first invaders, the tribes were split into two groups, the Avars and the Rus. Comprehensive schools have been accused of grade inflation after a study revealed that Gymnasium senior students of average mathematical ability found themselves at the very bottom of their peers on a common national test.

In addition, the study also showed that about half of the Gymnasium students were expected to score above the national average and only 22 percent had a chance of reaching this goal. The study, carried out by the German education ministry's public relations department, said that this discrepancy was explained by children not having a deep and broad understanding of maths.

"The Gymnasium class is becoming an elite, while the school average for the whole senior class is becoming a lower mark," a spokesperson for the education ministry told Welt. The university culture developed differently in northern Europe than it did in the south, although the northern (primarily Germany, France and Great Britain) and southern (England, Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland) universities are based on the same model, one of "research-intensive academic institutions." However, there are some significant differences from place to place.

Northern European universities are based on a number of things. The first of these is tradition, which is a combination of institutional memory and shared practices, as well as a way to connect the physical space of the campus to the mission of the university. Traditions also include a sense of belonging to an elite group with a tradition of excellence.

Another thing universities can be based on is a commitment to innovation: to the process of continually rethinking, redesigning, expanding and improving the educational and research programs on their campuses. Microbiological culture is a principal tool used to diagnose infectious disease. In a microbial culture, a growth medium is provided for a specific agent. Culture is usually performed by placing the growth medium in a microculture sample container, e.g., test tube, slide, test plate, petri dish, or chip. Samples that should be examined by microbiological culture are frequently introduced to the medium through a medium containing the sample agent that is to be cultured. Such media may be referred to as sample media. The media may also contain a nutrient supplement, e.g., a nutrient such as nutrients such as ammonia, magnesium sulphate, lactate, glucose, or sugar. The nutrients may also be added through the outer surface of the test plate, chip, petri dish, slide, or the like of a microculture medium. The nutrient addition may be by a droplet-feed method, e.g., an emulsion feed or a spray feed method.

While medieval pageants and festivals such as Corpus Christi were church-sanctioned, Carnival was also a manifestation of medieval folk culture. Many people involved in the festival took turns at the helm at the head of floats, and reveled in the opportunity to wear the most outlandish costumes.

To celebrate Carnival, one would celebrate this festival’s roots as “Festa San Marco,” which in turn derived from the celebration of the birth of the Holy Spirit on March 1 (originally celebrated as an Easter event).

The festival evolved to be a large religious, political, social and spiritual event which was open to nearly everyone in the town and region, serving as a source of relief from social and personal issues. It was also a source of recreation, the most popular being the masquerade ball, a carnival festival tradition which typically culminated in a great party ending with the wearing of masks, called masques.

Education in Israel is highly valued in the national culture with its historical values dating back to Ancient Israel and was viewed as one fundamental blocks of ancient Israelite civilization: education; community; religion; science & technology. Israel's educational institutions are well-structured and operated on the basis of meritocracy with very efficient standards, and thus are among the best in the world. Each of the higher education institutions is autonomous and distinct enough to be seen as distinct units.

As well as having highly qualified teachers, teachers in Israel also have the advantage of a unique working experience. Many of them either worked in the past decades in government-funded educational centers or studied in schools. After qualifying as educators, many of them went to work in their chosen fields while the others worked in more advanced education settings such as universities.

Adolescence marks a rapid change in one's role within a family. Young children tend to assert themselves forcefully, but are unable to demonstrate much flexibility and receptivity from an emotional or behavioral perspective. Children between the ages of 12-and 15-years-old, on the other hand, are often highly emotionally intelligent and well-mannered, but also possess a strong social conscience and a thirst for new ideas, knowledge, and social acceptance. This article's purpose is to provide parents with strategies for navigating adolescence in this rapidly developing phase.
Although children and adolescents are the most fascinating in terms of their growth and development, they can be extremely challenging. It is important to know that this adjustment period has some similarities not only to previous, but to future, life roles. Adolescence marks a rapid change in one’s role within a family and often requires an adjustment of lifestyle that results from the loss of a parent. The late 1980s saw a series of liberalising economic reforms within Libya designed to cope with the decline in oil revenues. In May 1987, Gaddafi introduced the “New Economic Policy,” which was to be based upon greater decentralisation, a decentralised state-owned economy, privatisation of state-run companies, deregulation of trade and exchange controls, and the development of a private sector driven by foreign investment. He believed that liberalisation could solve his declining oil revenues and improve the living standards of the Libyan populace, who had been subjected to a series of brutal dictatorships during colonial times and in the late 20th century, as well as his own rise to power.

Gaddafi’s hopes of reforming Libya’s economy were to be met with major resistance from the Gaddafi regime and its allies. Within the country, those who were close to the Gaddafi regime were most wary of any attempts to liberalise the economies, given those ties to the former colonial masters.

A 2010 study on Jewish ancestry by Atzmon-Ostrer et al. stated "Two major groups were identified by principal component, phylogenetic regression analysis. The first group included most of the Jewish immigrants born in Europe on religious grounds and on religious affiliation. The second group was constituted by converts of secular Jewish origin to Islam as their common origin, but whose background consisted mainly of secular Jewish immigrants to Arabic countries". They have also claimed that Jewish conversions in the Muslim world were "the main means" in the process of Islamisation and integration of Jews in Muslim societies, a position which is refuted by scholars such as Jürgen Habermas (2007).

The Atzmon-Ostrer study has been criticised by scholars such as Jürgen Habermas for being based on faulty statistical analysis and faulty methodology, arguing that "the results of the study are far from being convincing", and calling for a new inquiry.

Homer refers to the "Hellenes" (/ˈhɛliːnz/) as a relatively small tribe settled in Thessalonica. However, we should also take Homer's account of the events in his poem The Odyssey to be "history." The following account, from the first century AD, was written by a Roman historian named Suetonius, one of Suetonius' biographers. Suetonius' account is slightly different from Homer's, but much of it fits well with Homer's poem.

I met a man a little like you, with curly hair and small eyes: he was a barbarian from Thessaly. I saw him in the temple, and I thought I had the luck to meet the man whose life and deeds should be recorded in history. This man was a descendant from the Trojans, a Trojan horse.

The European concept of "race", along with many of the ideas now associated with the term, arose at the time of the scientific revolution, which first introduced an international standard for measuring the different ethnic differences that developed across Europe. The modern social doctrine of so-called racial discrimination was first articulated by the English physician Thomas Francis Knollys in 1773 in the first of many such writings, his book The Character and Genius of Man, as a defense of the concept that human populations had evolved independently across the continent and that race was an objective biological category that could not be defined mathematically.[36]

Historically, racial science has existed in many countries, sometimes as an explicit scientific doctrine (i.e., the eugenics movement) or with less explicit statements of the role of race in humans' social constructions. The Space Race was a 20th-century competition between two Cold War rivals, the Soviet Union (USSR) and the United States (US). From the early 1960s, scientists, engineers and mathematicians within United States federal agencies developed advanced technology to pursue orbital flight, the conquest of Mars, and scientific discovery on the Moon and elsewhere. From 1961 through the end of the Space Race in 1972, US astronauts made six manned manned flights to the Moon and back, two of which were flown by the Soviet Union.

A competition of this nature cannot be described as “fair.” When confronted by the superior human, machine, and technological capabilities of the other side, and the associated uncertainty of how to counter them, Americans, for a long time, chose to take the short road of building up their own capabilities to offset theirs.

In surveys made in Europe and the United States, green is the color most commonly associated with nature, life, health, youth, spring, hope, peace, tranquility and many other positive associations.
Green products and products related to nature are in high demand these days due to their ability to improve health and wellbeing.

Successful cultivation of cotton requires a long frost-free period, plenty of sunshine, and a moderate rainfall, usually from 600 to 1,200 hours per year. When a sufficient supply of food and moisture is available throughout the year cotton germinates and develops. Cotton is a perennial, propagating easily by soft root cuttings from plants, root or pollen from pollen grains, seed from pods and seeds. Once established, it is grown in warm sunny climates, and where the temperature is low the plants may be kept under cover or covered with a leaf, but even then it requires moisture to survive in winter. But this theory -- which says Mary simply existed prior to sinning -- has no place in Western thought. "The Church did not know how this concept of sinlessness came about," Sisler argues, "but she knew it was wrong."

In October 2014, the trial of six senior staff and journalists at The Sun newspaper began. All six were charged with conspiring to commit misconduct in a public office in relation to stories published in the newspaper involving the royal family. The offences related to the alleged breaking of British Editors’ Code of Practice (EPC), which sets out a code of ethics for UK journalists, with stories concerning the royal family.
The EPC is the UK’s top editorial code and is a statutory code. Its aim is to make journalists ‘fit for the job’ and ‘ethical’ by requiring that they ‘take responsibility for what they write’ and provide ‘accurate and fair’ information.
The court heard that the story about Meghan Markle’s father and son allegedly paying a private detective to gather information about her on an unauthorised basis was an EPC breach and an ‘unsanctioned’ private investigation.

The initial military maneuvers began in September 1806. In a notable letter to Marshal Soult detailing the plan for the campaign, Napoleon described the essential elements. On 25 September, some 2,500 French troops landed at Corbeil. Four days later, three larger divisions of 4,000 infantry and 3,200 cavalry set off for the English shore, while the remaining three divisions set out for a landing in France. The invasion was accompanied by a smaller division of 3,000 men led by Bonaparte in command of the 1st Guard Cavalry Corps. These troops, together with 200 sailors, landed at Perles, on 31 October. On 3 November, the large mass of infantry, cavalry, and sailors came ashore at Toulon.

In the spring of 1834, Chopin attended the Lower Rhenish Music Festival in Aix-la-Chapelle with Hiller, Pichon and Munch. The festival was an annual celebration held to mark the anniversary of the founding of the village, Aix-la-Chapelle. Chopin was invited as a member of the jury during one performance. While there, he developed an emotional attachment towards the festival, which he later incorporated into his score to the waltz Larghetto. The waltz he eventually gave himself the title "Gloria in Excelsis Deo et Deo Gratias".

Intel had tried unsuccessfully to push Apple to migrate the Macintosh platform to Intel chips. Apple concluded that Intel's CISC (Complex Instruction Set Computer) architecture wasn't enough in an application environment. Instead, Apple settled on the microarchitecture that is known today as X86, the 32-bit computing architecture that runs programs on IBM, HP, and Motorola processors. Some time after launching the first Mac in 1990, Apple turned to Intel to deliver microprocessors for the Macintosh II and the Macintosh Classic. In 2001, however, Apple went a step further and started to partner with other chip manufacturers, such as Advanced Micro Devices, to produce processors for its Apple-branded mobile devices. Jefferson and James Madison's conceptions of separation have long been debated. Jefferson refused to issue Proclamations of Thanksgiving sent to him by Congress. Madison refused to attend proclamations sent to him. They argued in both cases that the Constitution's enumeration of enumerated powers and separation of powers prevented them from celebrating a national Thanksgiving or granting them any other powers that would allow them to do so. It is this distinction, though not nearly a new one, that remains in debate today.

The historical and political background from which Jefferson and Madison were drawn was unique. They were both British subjects, the son of a British aristocrat, and they grew up in the world of British monarchic government. They were therefore intimately acquainted with English ideas about the nature of the British monarchy. For these British subjects, the very idea of an American republic seemed an anachronism.

Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people. An exclusive boundary arises, for example, when a person adopts an idea that others would consider to be ridiculous because he or she believes the idea is true. Conversely, a boundary can be inclusive when it is not based on true belief, and is open to reconsideration if new evidence arises.

A boundary has a set of limits that a person attaches to his or her life to define the areas of his or her life that are considered inappropriate to participate, enjoy, promote, or associate with. The purpose of setting boundaries is to limit our exposure to situations and activities that we believe may be harmful or destructive.

To maintain a high constant body temperature is energy expensive – mammals therefore need a nutritious and plentiful diet. While the earliest mammals were probably predators, different mammalian groups started living at a similar time, and with similar diets.

Mammals also share many features in common that separate them from other animals, including their metabolism, their digestive system and their senses.

For example, the brain of many mammals is larger than those of other animals. The average size increases with the size of the body, except in insects, which all have a smaller brain.

The largest mammals have brains larger than that of elephants. The average human brain is still smaller than most mammals which suggest that humans are the smallest mammals.

There are mammals which have brains that are equal to their body size including the hippo, the elephant and the chimpanzee, and many of them are larger than the largest mammal of all – the gorilla which is the only gorilla that lives in captivity.

It is not clear exactly where collegiate a cappella began. The Rensselyrics of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute (1848–1916) claim that: "The term came from the music class section of the gymnasium at the old Albany Academy, under Dr. Charles W. Gifford".

It is noted that a cappella originated in the school's singing class in the gymnasium. The phrase was first recorded by Thomas Wilkins, Rector of Christ Church, Rochester, New York. The phrase had come from a student's remark that he "couldn't think of anything". The phrase seems to have been later attributed to E. F. H. Liddel Hart. The most celebrated American poet to use the phrase is Stephen Vincent Benét, who used the phrase in his poem "Rennies" published in 1902 (see above). The origin of this phrase and the use thereof in poetry are unrecorded

The relationships adolescents have with their peers, family, and members of their social sphere play a vital role in the social development of an adolescent. As such, the importance of nurturing these relationships is self-evident. Relationships have been termed “critical dimensions” since they are the most crucial factors in the lives of adolescent citizens. For these adolescents, relationships, in particular with family, friends and the larger community, are key factors determining their development.

With adolescents' need to form relationships of affection, support and affiliation, the need for and value of relationships has increased and is being viewed as a fundamental human need. This need can manifest differently and will be met in different ways. The aim of this brief overview is to outline current data on adolescents' attachment relationships, as well as the associated developmental processes. Theoretical perspectives on human attachment and the understanding of the relationship between adolescents and their relationships will also be mentioned.

Before the early 20th century, treatments for infections were based primarily on medicinal folklore. Mixtures with antimicrobial properties that were used in treatments of that age included garlic, milk, fish and vinegar.

When antibiotics were first developed in 1928, their clinical role was to treat infections caused by gram positive bacteria — the category of bacteria that is responsible for the common cold. At the time of their invention, bacteria did not have a membrane that gave them resistance to antibiotics. Thus, no antibiotic resistant organisms were known.

In 1944, the United States Army issued a directive, which said that “antibiotics must have no residual toxicity [i.e. they need not be poisonous]” in order to be effective drugs.

The antibiotics that were developed by the pharmaceutical industry are still effective. However, overuse of antibiotics is leading to bacterial resistance because they act against a narrow range of proteins. In short, overuse is allowing bacteria to acquire resistance to antibiotics

Communication within peer groups allows adolescents to explore their feelings and identity as well as develop and evaluate their social skills. Peer groups offer members the opportunity to interact with peers from diverse social and ethnic backgrounds. This paper describes the development of a study to examine peer groups in elementary schools and to identify characteristics that influence peer group communication within the school environment. The research design utilized an exploratory quantitative research method and employed a multi-method approach, which employed secondary data collection to obtain qualitative data that was then used to design the quantitative research. The quantitative data included data gathered from qualitative interviews with parents, teachers, principals, staff members, and students, which was combined with data on school based surveys, and data from on site observations in the school setting and in after school programs and after school activities. The findings from both the quantitative and qualitative sources demonstrate that communication within peer groups varies, and that there are characteristics that influence interpersonal communication within groups. In 1681, in partial repayment of a debt, Charles II of England granted William Penn a charter for what would become the Pennsylvania colony. Despite the royal charter, neither Penn or the king signed the charter. Instead, the king had William Penn appoint a committee of four, including William Penn himself, to sign the charter on the king’s behalf. Penn chose Samuel Adams of Massachusetts, John Penn of England, Josiah Stamp of Connecticut, and William Penn of Pennsylvania to draft the document.

Chapter XI deals with evidence from biogeography, starting with the observation that differences in flora and fauna from separate regions cannot be explained by environmental factors alone. As well as arguing for a biogenic origin, he also argues that ‘the world in which plants grow … reflects life in its origin … plants and animals … are living things, capable of changing by changes, modifications in the form and composition of their tissues and their surroundings ‘ (25). This means that when we look at plants and animals across large geographical areas, we are also looking at them in their evolutionary origin. This idea that species share a ‘biogenic origin’ in the same way as species have shared a common origin in the distant past has remained a central theme throughout the history of biodiversity research.
