Sleep does not affect acquisition or recall while one is awake. Therefore, sleep has the greatest effect on memory consolidation. During sleep, the neural connections between neurons are stronger, allowing more of the brain’s chemical messengers (neurotransmitters) to transfer between neurons in the brain’s cortex and cerebellum, which is associated with memory formation.

The brain regions affected by sleep include the hippocampus, where memory is consolidated; the ventromedial prefrontal cortex and the insula, associated with mood and affect.

There is evidence to suggest that sleep may be essential for synaptic plasticity and neurogenesis. During sleep, the neurons in the frontal cortex and hippocampus are able to rewire. Although the exact biological mechanisms or process are uncertain, recent studies found evidence that sleep may help with neurogenesis, or the creation of new neurons (Figure 2).

Van Praag states that the Ming court established diplomatic delegations with Tibet merely to secure urgently needed horses. Wang and Nyima argue that these were not the purpose of the meetings in question, as the Tibetans clearly did not perceive the Ming diplomats as seeking horsemen: ‘Not one Tibetan would join our side of the caravan …’ Their interpretation of the Chinese diplomacy as essentially military in nature is therefore quite at odds with what we have already seen of the interaction between the court and the Tibetan population.

It is difficult to escape the conclusion that the court was actually concerned with securing access to Tibet for China and had no intention to engage with Tibetans for any other reason. The first railways in Thuringia had been built in the 1840s and the network of main lines was finished around 1880. By 1920, many villages still had only single track lines or even less than one track. As a result of the decline in car use in the rural areas, the traffic on the network declined, causing the railways to lose their usefulness as public transport.

Around 1970, the railway system had begun to be modernised. New line and signalling systems were built, and the railways became less expensive to run and more environmentally friendly. In 1986, part of the railway network with just nine kilometres of single track was replaced by high-speed lines. The modernisation of the existing network was carried out in the 1980s and 90s and the whole network was modernised in the 2000s and is therefore largely used by high-speed trains. However, other rail lines were also modernised and the remaining lines are mainly used for freight traffic.

Plumage is regularly moulted; the standard plumage of a bird that has moulted after breeding is known as the "non-breeding plumage."

Moult is a phenomenon that occurs in animals. A moult is the process where a bird changes its coloring and can result in a birds becoming a completely different bird in terms of appearance. Moults occur regularly, and frequently result from weather effects.  Plumage can undergo a complete moult within a single day. This is known as a "one-day-change" moult. However, a moult often occurs over several different days and years.  Moults can also occur for other reasons such as a bird undergoing a change in body temperature.

As cellular metabolism/energy production requires oxygen, potentially damaging (e.g., mutation causing) compounds known as free radicals can form. Most of the free radicals in the human body are generated in the mitochondria of the cell. Mitochondria form the powerhouse of the cell and produce the energy or ATP from carbohydrates, fats and proteins. When free radicals are present in the cells of the organism, the mitochondria can become dysfunctional. Mitochondrial dysfunction can lead to a breakdown of the cell, including release of damaging or toxic products into the organism.
Numerous chemical products such as glutathione, superoxide ion and hydrogen peroxide can play a role in the formation of the free radicals which damage mitochondria. A reduction of glutathione, e.g., from glutathione carboxylate (GSH) to glutathione hydrogen S-oxide (GSH-O) has been observed in numerous experimental settings over many years. This was an intellectual revolution, much the same one as arose in the physical sciences in the nineteenth century by the insight that you can, in principle, prove theorems about the nature of things. But the post-Humean conception of epistemological necessity has also proved hard to reconcile with the scientific method. As the sociologist of science David Fidler has noted, “the assumption of the scientific method is that hypotheses are justified — they are testable and hence falsifiable. The area of modern Zhejiang was outside the major sphere of influence of the Shang civilization during the second millennium BC. The Shang were a nation and an ethnic group that ruled by a social system called "taoism." The Shang were a non-feudal people. The Shang began in southeastern China, but expanded to neighboring Southeast Asia, which had earlier been subdued by the Shang.

The term "house music" is said to have originated from a Chicago club called The Warehouse, which existed from 1977 to 1983. Clubbers to the party would ask for "house music," which would cause a DJ to play a mix of new dance music. But what does "house music" mean? It isn't music used in a club. It's music that uses "house" in the sense of mixing a variety of music genres.

The term house music first surfaced in Chicago as well, though it wasn't the initial term used by nightclubs. In fact, it wasn't used at all until the warehouse. In those days, "house music" referred to a house mix, which was a mix of soul, jazz, funk, disco and other beats. A house mix incorporated many popular music genres of the late-'60s & '70s such as Disco, Funk, Afro-Caribbean Rock and Latin Music.

As Western Europe witnessed the formation of new kingdoms, the Eastern Roman Empire remained intact and experienced an economic revival that lasted into the early 7th century.

In the US a civilian airport must date back at least 100 years, and there were some exceptions for military airports before World War II. The independence of the Thirteen Colonies in North America in 1783 after the American War of Independence caused Britain to lose some of its oldest and most powerful colonies. In addition to the loss of British trade, there was a great loss of life on both sides. During the War of Independence, the British Army and Navy had been fighting on the side of the colonists. The British War of Independence was fought in America and in Great Britain and Ireland, but it had primarily been fought in North America. The new United States of America included all the colonies that had been part of the British Empire, which included the colonies of Canada and New England. Britain had also lost most of its trade since all of its trade with the colonies was controlled by Britain. In addition, Britain had a debt to pay off from buying the American colonies. To pay off the debt, Britain sold American bonds to foreign investors, but many of the bonds proved to be worthless, causing Britain to lose a lot of money.

Valencia is a bilingual city: Valencian and Spanish are the two official languages. Spanish is official in all of Spain, whereas Valencian in Valencia.

Copper occurs naturally as native copper and was known to some of the oldest civilizations on record. It has a history of use that is at least two millennia back from the use of bronze (an ancient Chinese civilization used a special copper alloy that would bend but would not shatter). Copper is known to be extremely hard and will not rust, as long as it is not exposed to corrosive chemicals or sunlight. Copper is a great conductor of heat and is used in many electrical, electronic, chemical, and other machinery, and is used in many other applications.

Copper was also known to the ancient Gauls (the ancient English people are also known as the Gauls), Carthaginians, and even Ancient Rome, which relied heavily on copper for copper work. This rule is expected to be finalized in the coming months.

In a number of countries, although being today generally considered similar institutions of higher learning across many countries, polytechnics and institutes of technology used to be separate institutions with different roles and characteristics on the academic level.  The term originated in the 19th century with the introduction of the "three-year course" by the British to the developing country of British India. Polytechnic and Technological institutes are often referred to as "technological colleges".

After the formation of the European Economic Community in 1973, this separation was largely replaced by the system in force in most countries in the European Union. Today, most students studying sciences at uni- and polytechnic colleges in Europe are studying at their "old" institute of higher education.

The islands are at relatively low altitudes, with central Ireland and southern Great Britain particularly low lying: the lowest point in the islands is Holme in West Donegal which is at 50 metres below sea level. The islands are also subject to strong winds and wave action and the waters around them are prone to deep sea fishing.

The islands also have a high density of seabirds for their size, with over 130 recorded species from the North Sea, Black and North Atlantic Oceans and the Mediterranean. The species recorded locally include gulls, oystercatchers, fulmars, storm petrels, kittiwakes and razorbills.

The Northern Ireland Museum offers both a display within its building on the islands and ongoing research on the birds found there in the Museum Research Laboratory.

Other notable bird species have been recorded locally including European night heron, Eurasian collared dove, Mediterranean stonechats and the local rare, non-breeding European puff

Democratic Party candidates were consistently elected to local office, increasing the city's ties to the South and its dominant party. In 1861, Mayor Fernando Wood of Philadelphia called for "a strong Union with the South." Wood was a key member of the Philadelphia Democratic Machine.

Southern sympathies and local government

In many cities around the South, Democrats outpolled Republicans, usually by a large margin.

Democrats who had campaigned for abolition at the U.S. Congress had the strongest bond with the South and the most sympathy for southern conditions. They were also the first political group to have been directly affected by the conflict. As a result, southern sympathies played a large role in Southern city politics from the beginning. Democratic politicians were among the first to raise money for the war effort. Southern politicians were also largely among the first to condemn the war. This relationship led to significant overlap between candidates' policies and parties' ideologies.

Different phases of digestion take place including: the cephalic phase, gastric phase, and intestinal phase. The cephalic phase is that part of the digestive process which is the process where cells in the digestive tract come together, forming a pouch around the stomach and intestinal walls. In the gastric phase, the food eaten is digested by the stomach muscles, and in the intestinal phase that part of the food which is digested by the intestines is expelled. The main difference between these phases of digestion is that the cephalic phase is the part which breaks down the food while the gastrointestinal system breaks down the food into pieces which can be absorbed into the blood, and the digestive system of the stomach and intestines is able to absorb all the nutrients from the food because of a specific function they carry out.

The number of species invasions has been on the rise at least since the beginning of the 1900s. Species are increasingly being moved by humans (both directly and via natural processes) far from where they were originally found, sometimes in unexpected ways, in unprecedented numbers, and with surprising persistence. Many species introduced to Europe in the 19th century were later found to successfully establish themselves in the UK, creating a species supercontinent or biozone in Europe (Hofmeyr and Zilberman 2004). In Asia, species from Europe and North America were introduced on a massive scale during both the 19th and 20th centuries, making them the main drivers of vertebrate extinctions in the region (Van den Berg et al. 2013). The introduction of plants into North America and Europe has been followed by similar trends of extinctions and introductions in Asia (Yamamoto et al. 2007). However, more recent trends have resulted in species invasions in Europe being less likely to be catastrophic

In the spring of 1800, Napoleon and his troops crossed the Swiss Alps into Italy, aiming to surprise the Austrian armies that had reoccupied the peninsula a few months earlier. For the next ten weeks, his French and allied troops marched northward, fighting their way through Italy toward Vienna, where they hoped to join up with the Spanish army that had entered that city through the Austrian lines a week earlier. When they reached the Carpathians, they were frustrated. Austria had already begun preparations to defend the frontier, and the combined French and Spanish troops found themselves in what seemed to be a quagmire. One of Napoleon's generals, Grouchy, suggested that Napoleon retreat to his camp and wait out the battle there. Napoleon rejected the advice, sending his aide-de-camp Lefebvre instead. The first significant work that expressed scientific theory and knowledge expressly for the laity, in the vernacular, and with the entertainment of readers in mind, was the Greek Philosopher Plutarch’s Lives.  In this work were included discussions of topics most likely to be encountered in the lives of common folk, such as medical advances and the development and uses of the library. The earliest surviving book, titled Life of Solon, was written in Greek in the 4th century BCE, although Plutarch did not include such works as the Bible in his early works.  The first book-length work for the general public was the De Natura Deorum, which was written in the 6th century BCE. This work included extensive descriptions of natural phenomena, such as the Sun and stars. In the middle ages, several manuscripts were discovered containing the writings of scientists, including Copernicus, who wrote that the earth, moon, and sun revolve around the earth.

They also have no respect or regard for other fans or authority figures at the event.

Although the term "Bleacher Bums" is a relatively common one, "Bleacher Bums at work" (as it has recently been coined) has been used as a means of insulting a member of the public for their behavior.

A common set of signs that the "Bleacher Bums" are using to disrupt the event is similar to a poster board from which they write graffiti, often referencing things the fans have done, or written about, or even in some cases, about someone else to get them to stop doing those things.

Some street trams (streetcars) used conduit third-rail current collection. The third rail was below street level. The tram picked up the current by passing over the third rail. The third rail, which was not insulated properly, arched enough to allow the current to flow around the tram, up the outside of the vehicle, into the third rail, and out below. The current arched out from the tram into the street, into the ground, through ground joints, and into power distribution lines. Third rail current can be very high, and damage the conductors or other parts of the power distribution lines.
If the conductors in the third rail were damaged or the conductors in the third rail joints were damaged, and the third rail current arched out, the problem often caused the tram to stop. In 1877, Thomas Edison invented the phonograph. Unlike the phonautograph, it was capable of both recording and reproducing sound. Despite the invention of the phonograph, however, the musical industry has remained largely untouched by the advent of sound recording. A large part of this is the lack of a standardized medium on which music could be recorded. The phonograph records used by the record industry were made as a result of patents granted to Edison by the U.S. Patent Office.
In 1929, however, after the phonograph proved to be an impractical recording tool for the musical industry, the patent was awarded to the RCA Corporation (RCA, or the Radio Corporation of America). In 1929, RCA began to develop a new commercial product. In 1930, the RCA Victor Victor 10 gram record was introduced, the first commercially acceptable commercial device for the manufacture and sale of records. To enforce his blockade, Napoleon launched an expeditionary force led by General D'Estaing in early 1805. The Austrian army and naval forces were unable to prevent the French invasion and were defeated at the Battle of the Dnieper River near Cherkassy.

In early December, 1796, Russian forces led by Count Alexander Alexandrovich Borodin and the Polish commander, Michał Piotrowicz, were defeated and forced to withdraw from Poland. A Polish-Russian war of alliance had ended in an embarrassing defeat for both sides.

Reviews of the various editions of Windows 8 have been mixed. Tom Warren of The Verge said that although Windows 8's emphasis on touch computing was attractive, "it's also full of compromises." On the strength of Windows 8's tablet features alone, though, it earns our Editors' Choice award for Windows 8 systems.

The tablet market has exploded in recent years, with numerous companies rolling out tablets powered by Google's Android operating system. Microsoft has introduced its own OS, Windows 8, which is designed to appeal to tablet customers. Users can dock their Windows 8 devices into the larger desktops that ship with their computers, enabling them to act like laptop computers, too. The Windows 8 touch interface is designed around a combination of touch-supported Windows applications, including Microsoft Office apps, and touch-only apps that can run on the desktop as well.

However, critics have criticized Windows 8 for its failure to bring many of desktop users' favorite Windows programs over to its new format

In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth, development, the generation of energy and the maintenance of cellular stability. Energy production by biological organisms is achieved by either chemical catabolism or by chemical phosphorylation, wherein ATP is used as the energy source of interest. Chemical catabolism is a process wherein an organism converts a macromolecule into a simpler molecule with the metabolic degradation of nutrients or the conversion of waste products of metabolism. Phosphorylation is a process wherein an organism produces organic phosphates. In the biosphere, these organic phosphates are a major nutrient source for a variety of biological organisms. Phosphorylation of proteins is performed for a number of reasons including the formation of phosphodiester bonds, the binding of a phosphite group to a protein, and the formation of a phosphorylated residue as a by-product or a product of a physiological reaction

From 1877 to 1878, the area suffered a rash of stagecoach robberies. Most notable, however, were the two holdups committed by Charles Lavelli, described as “the most notorious bank robber in history.”

On October 16, 1877, a mob of 50 people formed outside the bank and confronted Lavelli. After a few gunshots were fired, Lavelli took his getaway car and headed for his house, where he had previously hidden a stolen pistol.

Lavelli’s wife and son escaped to the house of their business partner, but Lavelli took refuge in their upstairs bedroom. The mob stormed the upstairs room, forcing Lavelli and his wife to open the door, but the mob members missed him by inches. Lavelli fired one shot from his stolen pistol, killing two of the five men, a boy, and three women. The next day, Lavelli led officials to his house

In 633 AD, Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran and conquered it by 651 AD, largely converting Iranian people from their indigenous faiths of Manicheism, Islam and Zoroastrianism. At that time, the Sassanian Empire was the richest in the world, and its rulers were known for their opulence and lavish lifestyles.

Today, Iran is a country with the world’s fourth largest economy, the seventh largest population, and is rich in natural resources. It is a country where people can worship freely of their own faiths, including Zoroastrianism. According to the government, about three million people are practising Zoroastrians today.

The Parsis first came to Iran in the seventh century AD, fleeing Muslim persecution in Persia. In the ninth century AD, some settled in Azerbaijan, and more arrived in Iran in the 11th and 12th centuries. They were mainly merchants who settled along the Caspian coast, as well as in other parts

Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by painting on a large scale, with a special emphasis on decoration. The main colour for decoration was purple, and the carons and tesserae were frequently carved with figures of saints. The carons were so successful that they were exported to Italy. The carons could be carved in any pattern, even animals, and they were produced on all sorts of surfaces including doors, windows, friezes, altarpieces and other decorative objects, especially for use in churches and the cloisters. On top of this a special style of the artist, known as the Carpenter, emerged, whose distinctive technique and style made Caravaggio a superstar for the rest of Europe.

The brief peace in Europe allowed Napoleon to focus on the French colonies abroad. Saint-Domingue had managed to acquire a high level of political autonomy via the influence of its British overlord, but in 1803 a crisis erupted after the British refused to hand over the new colony of Martinique. This provoked the uprising of the West Africa (now Haiti) rebels of the Haitian Revolution who declared the independence of Haiti on December 7th, 1804. In response, France invaded the capital city of New Orleans on July 4th in 1805 to stop the rebels. The invasion of New Orleans did nothing to help France, it instead provoked the United States to declare independence on July 4th, a process which led to the War of 1812.

Northwestern's School of Communication has been especially fruitful in the number of actors, actresses, playwrights, and film and television writers and directors for whom it has trained over the past few generations.

But recently Northwestern's School of Communication may have done even more for one young man. Last week, the University Press of Kentucky announced a deal that, at almost $18 million, will pay a new chair a substantial annual salary of nearly $5 million and include an even larger equity investment over his lifetime.

David Fitch, the new Northwestern Chair of Communication Research and Scholar-in-Residence, will succeed Gary Yellen, one of the most prominent figures in the university's communications history, whose $8 million post-doctoral professorship was named for him earlier this year. The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all, the Georgics, which gave rise to many later Latin poets, were the first epic verse in which a new type of poetic language was developed: the poem of the "mature Virgil." The mature Virgil was still in the early stages of his career, but the Georgics demonstrated that it need not be a hopelessly dead genre. The Georgics have survived in numerous translations, among the earliest and most faithful being in Aeneid translation, which has produced the most widely and most admiringly recognized version (and most likely the most complete). Though no English translations of The Georgics are yet complete, several scholars have now completed a translation that is very nearly complete. Languages have developed continuously, in the majority of cases, as a result of local interactions and migrations among different peoples. The process is generally influenced by various anthropological, anthropocultural, economic, and political factors. As written languages, there are a large number of variants that vary as a result of socio-cultural and linguistic processes, in conjunction with the political system of the region.

The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (primarily in the form of active volcano) and a small island with the highest surface elevation of 683 m (2,362 ft) a.s.l. The island is situated in the Southern Atlantic Ocean, just north and west of the island of Ascension. A small permanent population of just over 170 people resides on the island of Saint Helena during summertime and during brief periods throughout the year when ships carrying livestock arrive at the port in December. Saint Helena was a Spanish territory until its transfer by Napoleon Bonaparte to the direct administration of Great Britain in 1803. The only settlement on the island of Saint Helena is the capital city of Saint Helena. However, asymmetry of causation can be observed in a non-arbitrary way which is not metaphysical in the case of a human hand dropping money. A non-arbitrary asymmetry can be observed because of physical and chemical differences. In the case of a hand dropping a dollar, the left-hand side of the muscle and nerves that are responsible for hand movement are stimulated, while the right side is not. This asymmetry is easily observed through the use of a single-photon counting technique using a light-sensitive detector set up on the right side of a human hand (and a light-sensitive detector set up on the left side of a human hand). However, this asymmetry is not easily observed through any set up for detecting left or right handedness in other mammals like birds or monkeys.

The state seemed at relative calm compared to the rest of the country due to its close ties to the United States until 1841. In 1843 General Louis Napoleon Bonaparte (1804-1847) gained access to the territory through a failed coup and subsequently conquered Tunis, Tunisians and the coast. In exchange for this conquest, the State of Tunis made a treaty with Napoleon, guaranteeing France the entire Sahara. After 1848, the territory remained under French control but the constitution allowed the people to elect representatives who would then represent them in the state assembly. At the turn of the 20th century, the French were replaced by Italians who ruled as a puppet regime, while the country had to fight against local rebellions, with the last revolt being against Italian control in 1941. In 1961, France became a republic and, after a failed coup against President Habib Bourguiba in 1969, an internationally supervised referendum was held in 1974 for independence.

On 1 September 1870, the battle opened with the Army of Châlons, with 202 infantry battalions, 80 cavalry squadrons and 5 artillery batteries, leading, defending, and attacking on the right bank of the Yvelines, with heavy cavalry support behind. In the center, the French reserve, with its two field armies and two cavalry corps, attacked the German right flank commanded by Prince Ferdinand of Bavaria with the support of artillery, infantry and cavalry divisions. A decisive battle ensued on the left bank where the French reserve attacked the German center with its two armies and all its reserve divisions. Although the French managed to push the Germans off the Yvelines, the battle ended with the French victory.

John treated the interdict as "the equivalent of a papal declaration of war". He responded by attempting to punish Innocent personally and to drive a wedge between the clergy and the people. He wrote:
"I am obliged, I say, by the Church to show my resentment, and I think that I have a just reason to do so, if this thing was not an intentional and deliberate insult and the violation of a legal treaty."

Later history

After Innocent's death, the emperor Julian I asked the council to annul his death; this request was approved in 449 following Innocent's request for Julian's execution in 442, after Julian had rejected the council's opinion that a council should be held to decide his case. On 16 July and 21 March 450, an interim council was held to determine Innocent's successor, the churchmen being supported by Julian's brother Gaius, who was proclaimed emperor by a Roman mob on 25 July.

The Canadian football field is 150 yards (137 m) long and 65 yards (59 m) wide with end zones 20 yards (18 m) from the sideline. This means that even the narrow end zone of a regulation-sized football field measures slightly larger than a football.

The distance between each end zone is a measure called the "bailiwick distance" (also known as "bailiwick yards", "bailiwick yards plus 4 yards" or "bailiwick yards").

A kick of 70 yards (66 m) or a pass to or from a receiver who is 20 yards farther from the sideline than the kicker is called "kicking off" or "kicking off". A pass to either of the two kicking side goal posts (to the right of the kicker, with the goal posts as shown in the picture below) is called a "passing off" or "passing off to the punter". In 1939, the Bureau began compiling a custodial detention list with the names of those who would be taken into custody in the event of war with the Soviet Union or Japan. This was followed in 1941 by mandatory registration of American citizens and permanent residents. In March 1942, the Bureau began issuing deportation orders to immigrants from Germany, Italy, and Japan.  In 1941, the Bureau also began compiling a comprehensive list of Jewish refugees, but this list was only published in 1948.

The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia. The practice is sometimes referred to as “inbreeding of livestock.” The practice is more broadly understood to be a social/cultural tendency which has occurred in numerous indigenous human settlements over the course of millennia which, depending on species, is known as “cultivatisation” or “sustainable agriculture.” The specific practice of hybridisation in domesticated animals has been studied by researchers at a variety of institutions such as UC Davis and the University of Minnesota. However, the impact of hybridisation on animal welfare is rarely discussed in the context of domesticated animals such as horses and cattle.

A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, saw God as a kind of super-super-santa clause, while atheism was the concept that God did not exist. Most atheists today would consider what would have been ‘atheism’ as an absurd concept, and would probably not have associated atheism with any particular group or religion.

But in 1787 Pierre Renan published a book called La Atheistique De Monseigneur de La Bibliere, which was actually the first serious effort to associate atheism with an organised religious organisation.

Of major Canadian cities, St. John's is the foggiest (124 days), windiest (24.3 km/h (15.3 mph) gusts), and driest (60 mm (2.6 inches) of precipitation).

In fact, the city didn't get its first measurable rainfall until Oct. 6, and only had 9 mm (0.3 inches) since then.

The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s.

A decade after the school was converted to all-male status and established as a Catholic university, Notre Dame football team had a tremendous impact on popular culture for both Irish Americans and Catholics in the United States. Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical categories, the Landes, the Rheinland and the Swiss Lake District. The Landes comprises the flat areas and mountains where people live, often in small villages. The Rheinland is one of the most beautiful and popular tourist regions in Switzerland. It has an overall area of roughly 50,000 square kilometres and contains roughly two half again as many lakes. The lakes themselves have an area of 10,000 square kilometres. It extends from the Alps eastwards into the Southern Valais, down to the Swiss and Italian borders. The Swiss Lake District includes a total of 26 cantons lying in the North West, North East, Middle South and South East, which together are the largest canton area in Switzerland. It is characterised by dense forests, beautiful lakes and mountainous regions.

Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) is a good estimate for the winter season. Temperatures typically remain below freezing every day throughout the season.[4]

The City also has mild winters due to the sea air penetrating down to the ground and warming nearby bodies of water.[4] In February, temperatures can drop below zero ( −17 °F °C) in Boston, but more often occur outside of the city in January and February. The average annual temperature is 4 °F (−17 °C) lower than the national average of 29 °F (0 °C). Although temperatures are mild and the City offers outdoor activities, residents are exposed to cold air on and after windy days. Boston has an average of 8 days of precipitation each year.[4]

As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf.
